page.title: 19THE BLUEBELL RAILWAY
page.content: 25 years ago steam trains were still part of every day life but fast disappearing. Railways declined with the coming of motor transport. In 1948 railways in Britain were nationalised and British Rail began closing uneconomic lines. Despite protests the Lewes to East Grinsted line finally closed in 1958. A year later the Bluebell Line Preservation Society was formed and purchased 4 half miles of line. They began a limited service in 1960 (this year it celebrates its quarter century ) Thanks to much voluntary effort. The railway now runs the whole 5 miles to Horsted Keynes daily in summer Sundays and Bank Holidays throughout the year (not Christmas Day) It employs 12 full-time workers and about 400 part-time voluntary helpers. {D Skan
